I'm usually a big fan of Prof. Krugman. I admire his analysis, as well as his tenacity in spreading his message. But with his latest favorite theme of bashing Germany, he's got some things wrong. I think what is happening, is that he is putting Germany and recalcitrant Republicans into the same mental box. And that is just wrong. Republicans politicians do what their big donors tell them to do. And they decidedly don't mind, if America suffers, while a Democrat is President. But in Germany, it's not a case of ill will. Sovereign member states with a common currency pose an untenable situation. Either the Euro has to go, or  european political integration has to become much tighter. Corruption has to go down, productivity has to increase, spending has to become more coordinated, and better off countries have to subsidize those less well off. Ms. Merkels only real bargaining chip is money. But she can only open her purse once. So while Krugman impatiently demands for the money to be spent and have it done with, Merkel also is trying to get some politically sustainable rules in place.

In 2004, Krugman explained "Why Germany Kan't succeed", only to see it rise to the worlds most competitive nation, with exports ahead of China, the US, and Japan.

Now he is complaining that Germany is succeeding too much, claiming that it occurred at the cost of its neighbors.

His analysis is wrong. Germany success is due to structural reforms, that France and Southern Europe still have implement.

Ms. Merkel's consistent has been financial support, yes, but only in return structural reforms.

Her aim is and has been to make Europe, in toto, more internationally competitive, An an extremely competent politician, she mighy just know better than an economists, who wrongly predicted the collapse of the Euro, on how to go about it.

Tim,

The drop in oil prices isn't enough to offset the steady rise in prices we've all been seeing at the grocery store since the onset of the Great Recession. Staples like milk, bread, eggs, meat, vegetables, non-food items - all have risen, not due to inflation, but due to lack of demand, to compensate for lower sales.

To give examples anyone can identify with...

The same steak I used to buy at $6-7 now costs $13-14. Stores have adjusted and readjusted the stock they carry, especially perishable items. Where I live, the grocery stores more often than not will run out of staples rather than carry ample stock, and the variety in any given category of item has been greatly reduced.

I've been watching other shoppers whenever I go to the store and I see an awful lot of well-dressed people turning items carefully, looking at prices and then putting the item back. Young people are doing this. Middle-aged shoppers are doing it. Older shoppers are definitely doing it. I live near my town's tony mall. The parking structure had plenty of parking in it this weekend.

Today's reports about Black Friday may well portend more bad news for us, rather than a shift in buying habits from brick and mortar stores to online retailers. We'll see...

Actually, Libertarians who are true to their roots in Ayn Rand's Objectivist philosophy ARE Anarchists, but are not Nihilists, and believe the world can magically have anarchy without having chaos. According to Rand, that is.

Of course, it's absurd. Every collection of people establishes an order and set of rules, and a mechanism to enforce those rules. They may be just and democratic, or they may be arbitrary and benefit the strongest and meanest in the group: The Thug. The history of most of the world is of Thug vs Thug. What is a king, a kaiser, a czar, a shah, a khan, a dictator, but a glorified thug, no different than a drug lord or a mafia godfather?

You can pretend that corporations function according to Rand's rules, but they don't. They demand unrestricted freedom from regulation when it comes to profits, but expect us to provide THEM a "collective" to absorb their costs. Thus WalMart expects us to subsidize their poorest workers, Exxon expects us to subsidize their oil explorations and the giant pharmas expect us to subsidize their research into new antibiotics, because they aren't as profitable as ED drugs.

I'd say that the state exists for "restraint" primarily, and "benefit" indirectly or, at best, secondarily.  I think that's where the Libertarians get it wrong - the belief that governmental control and restraint are not really necessary.

Liberty and license - I just love hearing Libertarians debate that topic. They try so hard to come up with so many fancy lies to cover up the actual truth: Liberty is whatever they want to do; License is whatever stands in their way.

Prof. Terrell makes the mistake of confusing libertarians with anarchists. Libertarians believe, as Aristotle did, that men are a political animals, and by nature form constitutional governments to promote their respective pursuits of happiness. Essential to those pursuits is liberty, not to be confused with license, which a freedom of action that only anarchists embrace, not libertarians.

The "fundamental philosophical difference" between liberals and libertarians, therefore, is one of degree: how much of one's individual liberty must one give up to further the end of one's own happiness? Liberals and libertarians differ on that question substantially. The answer lies on some optimal point along a scale.

Dr. Terrell is on the right track, but could be clearer. The individual is a social construction--we are able to construe ourselves as separate individuals because our culture provides the conceptual forms to do so (this is a distinctively modern, Western capability). Social contract theory (whether Rousseau or Locke) is pure myth. And we don't need to conflate society with the state--they're two quite different things. Still, community precedes individuality, both historically and logically, and it follows that individuality is morally subordinate to community.

Republicans will never support a jobs program because employed people put upward pressure on wages.

They throw the word "jobs" around at every opportunity, but it is just a word that people want to hear. Corporate profits trump infrastructure every day in the right-wing universe, and under/unemployment keeps "labor costs" -- a.k.a wages -- low.

Simon Wren-Lewis has made the point that Germany seems to have entered the Euro area at a competitive exchange rate. That means, that no, wages weren't really too high, even though that was the orthodoxy at the time. Of course, lowering those wages helped Germany through the early adjustment of the euro area bootup as it were. But your feeling that wages in the export area are extremely high are just that: feelings. The numbers don't bear it out.

Given that Germany at the time joined the euro area at a competitive rate, this means that it should over longer periods of time run a 2% inflation. If it didn't for a few years, then in the following years it should catch up, i.e. Germany should currently be running at least 3% of inflation to bring its economy in line with the rest of the euro area. I guess this is a point we didn't realise at the time the euro was introduced, but that's really what the inflation targets of the ECB results in.

In effect, Germany is consistently targeting below 1% inflation, which we know to be a Very Bad Idea. Looked at in those terms, it's only natural that Germany should boost demand by "over"investing. Only of course, the German government and public is still stuck in a structural reform mindset, and seemingly will continue to be so for the next few years.

I really don't see how anyone could claim - with a straight face - that Germany had competitive wages in 1999. That's just absurd. German unemployment was rising (because it's wages were so competitive?), GDP growth was about to come to a halt after the 2000-boom for basically 5 straight years in a row. And actually unions - I repeat: unions (and yes, this still means sth. in Germany) - realized that German wages were too high compared to other countries.

I also don't see how you could possibly claim that Germany is consistently targeting below 1% inflation. I'm sorry, but you are just making things up. Actually, German inflation rate has been above 1% for every year since about 2000, except for 2009 and probably 2014.

While I understand why Mr. Krugman would choose 1999 as the starting year for the comparison (it's the first year of the Euro after all), it's nevertheless very problematic. In 1999, Germany had too high wages and simply was in desperate need of having smaller wage growth rates than the other Euro countries.
It is also worth noting that Germany still has extremely high wages in many of those export oriented businesses. To me it seems ridiculous to point to Germany and act like they should have higher wages. The wages are already high!
